title: every single report ive ever gotten has been due to me replying to toxic people, Now im banned.
body:
Literally every single report ive ever gotten has been from me replying to someone who was toxic to me first. I just got banned in a match where my teamates decided to to troll me by flashing into me with zil bombs to kill me. Not one teamate, 2 of them. i then AFKd (it was ARAM and they were obviously premade. If they want to troll randoms, then fuck them)

Then they said "what a useless waste of life"

I said dont troll people next time then he devolved into the typical teenager thing of "i trolled you and its your fault for being mad at it lmao look at this guy so mad" etc etc.

Enemy team jumped in, "what a bitch for afk". Like if they wanted to win the game, why are they flashing into low health teamates with zil bombs on them? Makes zero fucking sense.


Just so its clear I hadnt said or done ANYTHING towards them at all. Completely unprovoked trolling by a premade.
this is just _this_ match, every other report ive gotten has been me replying to toxic people. There seriously needs to be a system that checks things better. Im sick of getting punished even though im the victim.

Getting the chat log on the ban screen saying "this is why you're banned" and it _fucking shows that IM the one who was the victim_ is infuriating.

replies.body:
We get at least one of these a day...

Responding to trolls is the worst thing you can do.

You are no longer the victim when you decided to flame them back.

It takes 2 people to have an arguement.

I disagree. Im obviously the victim in this last match. They were literally picking up zil bombs and flashing on to me when i was low hp, with absolutely zero provocation. Then I told them not to troll people next time as I afkd on the match. They had been trying to run the bombs to me but started flashing them onto me. I wasnt going to spend the rest of the match dealing with that.


And it should definitely be a mitigating factor in dealing with reports if you've replied to someone who's being toxic vs starting it. You're still _the_ victim. If you're never toxic in the slightest without someone doing it to you first, thats a LOT different than being toxic first.

I think the fact that all 4 members of my team were picking up zil bombs and trying to explode them on me for the entire match, even using flashes to kill me with them, is enough justification to AFK in an ARAM.

Do you honestly disagree? This community is something special. But I get it, this place is not for me. Uninstalling now. Bye guys. Enjoy this stupidity. Glad I bought some dish sponges instead of RP.

You're being taught in kindergarten that it doesn't matter who started. It takes 2 people to have a fight if both sides participate.

You retaliated in a way that is obviously against the rules, thus you get your own treatment, regardless of what provoked you.
If you didn't do so you wouldn't have gotten punished.

Tbh I don't get what's the point of being toxic in return to someone else being toxic. Do you want to explain?

The problem is in League, the kid who started it is being allowed to put on another mask and continue to pick fights with kids.

I would personally go on and pick a fight with the staff if my kid were banned from going in without a mask (the original, true mask) because they got in a fight with a kid with a mask.

And I would reward my kid if they won. But if it was with another kid without a mask, my kid is going to learn manners.

Point is in real life I won't put up with absolutely unacceptable behavior, and League needs to put the human side back in.

In how far are they "allowed to pick fights"?

If 2 kids fight and the teacher only sees one party i.e. shove the other, but clail the other one started, they both have to shake hands and make up. But that's not the case for league.
Riot can see both participants' actions, so accordingly they punish both, if it's punishable. If the teacher sees both kids shove each other around, they are both gonna go to detention or make up or w.e.

For reference, I know a handful of people working in kindergartens and asked first hand. If you were taught something different, your teacher was doing wrong.

Again, the problem is that one party has the ability to be completely immune to punishment- in League, an unknown number of people are able to circumvent the punishments by having access to potentially unlimited accounts.

As mentioned, in the school analogy, it would be as any kid being exempt from punishment so long as they put on a new mask, and nobody could stop the kid from doing so. And then, even knowing that this kid exists, going ahead and fully punishing every kid that this exempt kid gets in a fight with. Imagine that for a second.

Your friend is a good kid to everyone who is fair. Even the slight annoyances they put up with. Then comes this kid Joe who just shoves your friend aside in the lunch line, and when you say "hey,", the kid turns around and punches you in the nose. Your friend without hesitation screams for help. The staff arrive, and grab the three of you for questioning. Your friend is punished for screaming, you get let go, and they're about to send the kid home when he just puts on a smile and says, "My name is now James," and the staff respond, "Oh, well Joe is suspended, we'll just take Joe's stuff from you, then just run along James."

Even if it were just one kid in three hundred, that's a serious problem. Not an exaggeration.

Of course in a real school no kid could get away with that. That's why I'm saying this punishment system is bad, because in League, there are many kids like this getting away with it. Sure, the system is banning those accounts, but the point is that the banning is COMPLETELY INEFFECTIVE against those prepared for it.

Okay so I still have no idea what exactly you're talking about, but I asume you mean somene that creates new accounts to force people into these debates to get them banned? Please correct me if I'm not aware of some blatant loophole in the system that lets you get no punishment.

If you mean those recreated accounts, well.. 
a) how many people are actually willing to waste their time getting people banned in an online video game, by having to level new accounts over and over again,
b) how could you ever stop them from doing so? If you knew an effective way, I'm sure Riot would be burning to know,
c) your analogy is wrong, you don't get banned for screaming for help, but for retaliating. If you can't keep your composure, that's your own fault,
and d) what stops you from creating a new account as well?

Recreated and bot-built accounts, the latter of which requires a purchase with a 3rd party, unless clever enough to build the bot. These players don't force the debates, but blatantly disregard the rules and say and do whatever they want in game. They can be extremely toxic to the point that even normally good players can easily lose their cool, trying to play with the player who does not play by the rules. Professional players refuse to play alongside such players, and it's unreasonable to PUNISH players who are exposed to such extremes. There is a line, but right now Riot's line is so far into pandering that it is no longer giving heed to the human side of the players. Many do not have a problem anyway, but "works for most" is a moral failure to the few- the few who are just exhibiting normal human behavior that is not wrong.

"Never retaliate" is wrong. Especially in a game where killing is the practical path to victory. Not everyone can maintain mental fortitude accepting abuse, and must defend themselves. Remember, as humans, we have different needs, and many have a need to not sit quietly and be verbosely punished in a game they're trying to play, not to mention being subjected to a 4v6 by a hostile ally.

a) Purchasing accounts is a real thing. There are those willing to just do the time as well. I see many no-skin players... given how many bots there are, it's obvious there are many. We don't know how many bots, but each one is intended to be sold or used- unless they're some freak experiment by a programmer trying to gather data. I can think of no other reason for so many bots.
b) Without being intrusive to players, there is no way to stop them. But there are ways to incentivize not doing so, for starters, do away with bans for all but the most wretched cases. This would be an extensive discussion.
c) you're assuming screaming is not punishable. I'm surprised you expect people can't be punished for screaming. It is unusual, but so is pulling the trigger for saying "money fuck" and "delusional" on a player who has shown clear signs of attempting to reform. Indeed, many punished players are doing nothing but saying "you're going to be reported for that behavior". Yes, saying "I'll report u!" is considered offensive, but it is also a very reasonable response. This is only a universal offense because the system does not account for context or intent, and it very well should if it's banning accounts that could mean a lot to players, both financially and emotionally.
d) ABSOLUTELY NOTHING... except I have no reason to! I'm a good, rule abiding player who is calling out the system as lacking and suggesting solutions, even looking to get the ball rolling on reforming the system.

> b) Without being intrusive to players, there is no way to stop them. But there are ways to incentivize not doing so, for starters, do away with bans for all but the most wretched cases. This would be an extensive discussion.

I'm not willing to discuss the point of bans here, even if I think it's a ridiculous idea to remove them.
But even if you'd do so, how does that stop people from extensive toxicity? You don't even punish them by forcing them on new accounts and all the negative aspects that come with it.

> c) you're assuming screaming is not punishable. I'm surprised you expect people can't be punished for screaming. It is unusual, but so is pulling the trigger for saying "money fuck" and "delusional" on a player who has shown clear signs of attempting to reform. Indeed, many punished players are doing nothing but saying "you're going to be reported for that behavior". Yes, saying "I'll report u!" is considered offensive, but it is also a very reasonable response. This is only a universal offense because the system does not account for context or intent, and it very well should if it's banning accounts that could mean a lot to players, both financially and emotionally.

Screaming for help, aka reporting isn't punishable. Calling names/retaliating =/= screaming for help.
"I'll report you" is not punishable, only in spam. Asking for reports _is_, but it's something different than the claim to do so.

> d) ABSOLUTELY NOTHING... except I have no reason to! I'm a good, rule abiding player who is calling out the system as lacking and suggesting solutions, even looking to get the ball rolling on reforming the system.

Good, same. But why would you think the system isn't optimized? What does Riot gain from punishing "abiding players"?
I'm of the opinion returning an optimized Tribunal would make the system better, but as a singular system, the automized one is the best you can get.

I say there is a reason to retaliate- to defend the ego. Yes, it is generally not the best way to deal with flames, but nor is stoic silence an acceptable option for everyone. We are all different in our self-awareness and it is not a single, rising path. Some *must* defend themselves, be it a fragile sensibility, a need to assert oneself, or, best of all, simply intensify their own emotional fuel. Anger leads to creativity and ambition, and can assist in communicating.

Seriously. "The angry man is aiming at what he can attain, and the belief that you will attain your aim is pleasant." -Aristotle

This means that angry players- now generally speaking- are more motivated to win, and pushes them harder to positively solve problems. I don't mean in a care-bear manner, I'm talking about effective, practical, non-destructive reasoning to learn and adapt on the fly. Mental fortitude, as mentioned earlier. Stoic play is opposite to this.

Added to that, being angry and solving a problem is outright *pleasurable*. We humans *love* to get angry and then solve problems. Winning is rewarding, but it is much more satisfying when we were angry.

Individuals who can make use of this are not inherently bad for the community. Some only let the anger rise in response to flaming, and not only is this a natural human response... it is a GOOD response if tempered with reason. Venting allows people to focus. By restricting people's ability to retaliate, most players continue to be angry without having been able to vent. Now, real common sense here, what happens when you bottle up anger like that?

Ya blow up. Every. Last. Human. Will. Blow. Up. Eventually. You HAVE to vent, or stop getting angry.

_**League of Legends is an excellent game to play angry, if you're thinking "don't play League when angry", you're wrong.**_

As long as that anger is not used destructively, as in any scenario.

Retaliating itself, as mentioned earlier, can assist in communicating. Firstly, it can help mitigate or even eliminate hostility. Showing some dominance or confidence in ego pushes back on most people-

"Pleeb can't last hit the cannon minions",  "i CAN and WILL, just stop pushing me to keep trying to protect your ass with your overaggressive pokes!"

...and the point is NOT that this is okay with the rules, but I insist it should be. The stoic approach would have the ADC remain silent and continue doing their best, be it now focusing on cannons and not help the support's aggressiveness or keep doing what they did to illicit the flame in the first place.

An angry retaliation will give a third option: focus on cannons with the support aware that the ADC needs to focus on it. Yes, a stoic person can actually achieve this- but as said, it requires someone who is comfortable with that approach, who is cool-headed in the first place. You can't ask an angry person to be stoic and expect them to perform well.

Lastly, I'll touch on why bans are bad. Again, actually.

Because they're entirely ineffective on some, and those individuals go on to be *extremely toxic* and spread suppressed anger like an out of control oil geyser, turning the League community into a primed keg for eventual explosive and destructive eruptions of anger.

Yes, it's a good answer to the majority, where banning is effective. This is why it is a moral failure on the few- it's not just to feel good about doing the right thing, it's to make the game better. It's not just the consistently reactive banned players suffering from the extremely toxic individuals, it's everyone, only a few are really suffering.

How's that for cracking the common perception?

I can see where you're coming from with your theory, but there's 4 problems with it.

1. It's distracting. The reason why you're supposed to mute people isn't mainly because what they say hurts (imo). It's to let you focus on playing the game and not get distracted into a senseless discussion with some kid trying to vent it's problems.

2. If you don't succeed in better communication/play, it's gonna blow up regardless, with even more fuel at that.

3. You undersetimate how quickly people are to give up. Especially in this meta where a single mistake can lose you the lane, any kind of returned flame can easily bring people to afk, troll, etc. That is not just about you as the flamed player, as flame often originates from losing in some aspects of the game (e.g. a failed gank/combo). Otherwise there would be no reason to flame in the first place.

4. If we're talking about one of those people who flame for the sake of ruining others games, it won't matter. Not only will they continue to ruin the game, but you also fulfill the first 3 points _and_ give these people the satisfaction of the reaction they wanted.

About the bans:
If you're to let people just do as they please without bans, others won't hesitate to do the same, since they don't see any drawbacks.
I also fail to see how not banning the extreme individuals would be beneficial to those who suffer to their toxicity right now.

All 4 points I agree with- indeed, retaliation generally isn't the best response. But it isn't inherently a *wrong* response, tempered with reason and purpose. Stoic silence isn't the only answer, the point is that retaliation has merits and the 4 bad points (which aren't always applicable nor does one always have to occur) do not invalidate retaliation as a force toward a positive outcome.

If bans were removed, an alternative punishment system would have to take its place. While I believe it is meritable to continue discussing that, I really only meant to say for now that ban style punishments are not a good solution for League.

So, it has come to this: someone displayed misbehavior in a LoL match in flagrant disregard for the game's rules, ToS, EULA, and Summoner's Code. That's unfortunate, and I'm sorry you had to deal with it. If this misbehavior happened in chat (including emotes or ping) and they don't respond positively to a _single, courteous, constructive request to focus on the game_, your best option is to mute that player. Submit a report after the match. This is equivalent to dealing with a noisy person in a library by asking them to keep it down and then notifying library staff and moving to another area.

_Do not respond with misbehavior of your own!_ If you do that, your teammates may report _you_, and those reports would be valid. This is equivalent to dealing with a noisy person in a library by getting into a shouting match with them. Just because someone else started it doesn't justify you in continuing it. I'm sure you're familiar with the "s/he started it" trope, where two children get into an argument or fight and then try to claim innocence of any wrongdoing by claiming that they didn't instigate it. As any parent, teacher, or other supervisor of children will tell you, that excuse doesn't fly. When Dad is trying to drive you to Disneyland and your annoying brother starts making faces at you as he's previously been told not to, you should calmly ask him to stop, and then, if that doesn't work, calmly notify your parents of the problem. Making faces at him or shouting at him has never been a good way to get him to stop, and it makes you just as guilty of that as he.

Riot doesn't care who started it. Someone else's misbehavior does not justify your own.

From [Riot's support knowledgebase](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/207489286-Instant-Feedback-System-FAQ-):

> * Simply speaking, retaliation is not an acceptable or justifiable behavior. An argument between two players can easily create a negative experience for the rest of the players in the game with you. Regardless of the other player’s actions, this does not justify your own behavior. You alone are responsible for your actions within the game.If you encounter a toxic player like this, the best option is to simply report their behavior and move on.
> * Reports are a vital piece to the puzzle. If you are not sure of what sort of behavior is reportable take a look at the [Reporting a Player FAQ](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752884-Reporting-a-Player)

And this is why I mute chat. Because Riot doesn't allow you to stand up for yourself. Meaning, you aren't allowed to retaliate! If you do, you get punished. Then, just mute everyone from the get-go so you don't see them type nonsense. I mean, its either that or just not playing the game because no one likes to listen to crap from strangers and take it like a little bitch.

How many games do you get where someone just starts spouting nonsense without any provocation at you or someone else on the team? I dare say that atleast a little less than half or even more depending on the times you're playing at. That's just _tilting_.

Then there are some exceptional cases. I saw one OP who I admired quite a bit because he spoke about how if someone says something to him in chat. He just doesn't accept it, it doesn't affect him. He talked about how he learned to control himself better and how strangers saying something to him was irrelevant. It makes sense. But this was one post/thread out of like dozens like the current OP's. I've not seen a similar post since! So my point is, most people who play the game are going to have the mindset like this. "You slap my face, I'll slap you back!" And some might even go on to say that they will not only slap your face but also kick it down for starting it. That's the standard response. But I'm interested to see if Riot keeps implementing this current system or revamps it to a newer one.

Conclusion? Just mute chat OP. Good luck with your future games. {{sticker:galio-happy}}

Playing poorly is not bannable. Playing poorly **intentionally** is.

Understanding that poor gameplay behavior is harder to catch is not "arbitrary".
